content.title: Carotid Body Tumor Resection
content.definition: Surgical excision of paragangliomas arising from the carotid body at the carotid bifurcation, requiring careful dissection to preserve neurovascular structures.

key_concepts.description: Neuroendocrine tumor arising from chemoreceptor cells at carotid bifurcation. Typically benign but locally invasive. 5-10% malignant.
Type I: Minimally attached to vessels, easy resection. Type II: Partially surrounds vessels. Type III: Encases carotid vessels, may require vessel resection.
Selective angiography with embolization 24-48 hours prior reduces blood loss for larger tumors.

clinical_features.presentation: Painless neck mass, pulsatile, mobile side-to-side but not vertically (Fontaine sign)

associated_syndromes.hereditary: 10-50% familial, especially if bilateral or multiple

clinical_features.functional: 5% secrete catecholamines - screen with plasma metanephrines

preoperative_workup.genetic: Consider genetic testing for SDH mutations

surgical_technique.approach: Standard anterior cervical incision along SCM
key_steps: Control common, internal, and external carotid arteries
Dissect in subadventitial plane along vessels
Identify and preserve vagus, hypoglossal, superior laryngeal nerves
Ligate feeding vessels from ECA branches

options: Internal carotid artery resection with interposition graft
Patch angioplasty if partial vessel wall resection
shamblin_III_technique.shunt: Consider shunting if ICA clamped for extended period

complications.bleeding: Significant in larger tumors without embolization
complications.first_bite_syndrome: Pain in parotid region with first bite - sympathetic disruption

learning_objectives: Classify carotid body tumors using Shamblin system
Describe preoperative workup including functional assessment
Explain surgical technique for resection with vessel preservation
List cranial nerves at risk and management of injury
clinical_pearls: Always screen for bilateral tumors and catecholamine excess
Dissect in subadventitial plane - tumor peels off vessel
Consider genetic testing - up to 50% may be hereditary
